column5: Too much text on the red, maybe use icons or other ways to simplify getting that info across and offer ways to get to alternatives such as the garages mentioned
column9: Need a "you are here" , differentiation of the thickness of lines on the green/by importance of information
column13: Contextual "where am I" in relation to the suggestions, also too much text, maybe have parking availability ranges 0, 1-3, 4+, and parking capacity
column17: Feels like construction roadsigns, may need to capture if it's two way or one way traffic and on which side of street
column18: Prototype 3 - Garage comparison with walk-distance slide
column19: Garage is most straightforward, if street parking need to indicate which side of street, two way or one way traffic

column18: Prototype 3 - Garage comparison with walk-distance slide

column5: "Warning to tell you difficult to parking" is best
column9: Perfect, very like "different colors to show how the parking is busy"
column17: Colors to tell you how parking is

column5: A quick drop expand arrow to have a quick glance at the proposed path on a map.
column9: Add street names for the side streets. Differentiate the location marker from the other lines, the red on red makes it hard to spot. Hide the legend since it blocks some of the view. Add indicators of parking limits. Even if parking is open, sometimes streets have 2 hour limits when you're going somewhere for 4.
column13: Reduce the amount of text. Also the pricing is not clear if that's per hour or expected $ amount for my intended parking. The intended parking time can span multiple price tiers and that's part of the consideration.
column19: 2 & 4 combined would help a lot. However, this is hard to compare because option 3 is just for garages.

column9: Focus only on streets with ample parking
column13: It only focuses on garages and none of the street like the other prototype
column17: It seems to be overly simple, maybe a bit more details would be nice
column19: People like to know exactly what to do, which is why everyone uses navigation even when driving to a destination they know the path to

column5: I think you could reduce cognitive load while driving by letting users start navigation with a single button. The default could guide them to street parking, and if they prefer garage parking, they could simply press an “alternative” button. This way, they wouldn’t need to pick a destination first and then tap “start navigation.”
column9: I think you could change the destination pin color so it doesn’t blend in with the difficult-parking roads.
column13: I think you could reduce the amount of on-screen text and use color or visual styling instead. This would keep the interface cleaner and make key information easier to understand at a glance.
column17: Universal icons for parking (e.g., a check mark, exclamation point, or “X” symbol) in addition to color.

column9: Labeling library or point of interest, not just street
column17: I have no idea what it’s trying to convey

column9: The ability to hide the colors of streets not meeting some requirment(i.e. only show lots of parking streets)
column17: A better idea of what availabilty means for each direction is that on street or if I follow it will it eventually take me to agrage
column18: Prototype 3 - Garage comparison with walk-distance slide
column19: I think prototype 1 and 3 would combine the best and make parking easier and quicker

column5: Focusing on the type of parking and respective likelihood at the destination. Eg Street Parking - Difficult. Parking Garage - Moderate (maybe incl price). Valet - Easily available etc
column9: The location marker and red colored streets were clashing. Feature wise maybe a secondary marker for the parking spot that also then shows the quickest walking path to the final destination.
column13: Not displaying the closed lots. Only providing top 2-3 options with only 3-4 bits of info like price, walking distance from destination, safety/rating. Tapping a choice should reveal further info like location, spots etc
column17: Some indicator on how far you are from the destination.

column5: Alternative parking structures with added delay times
column9: Traffic details. Who's who l going to what location, especially if everyone is going to the green zones
column13: I'm not exactly sure what the green check mark means. Is it referring to time it takes to park, time to get there, time delay?
column17: If this is signage, how would it change? Is this electronic signage? Is someone out there actively updating the sign? How would this be reliable?

column5: Add clearer real-time availability indicators instead of relying only on mode switching.
column9: Make the color-coding legend persist on-screen so drivers don’t have to recall meanings.
column13: Surface the walk-distance slider more prominently and show estimated walking times.
column17: Increase contrast and add directional arrows pointing to the nearest available area.
column19: A combination of Prototype 2’s color-coded street overlays and Prototype 4’s dynamic signage for both pre-arrival awareness and real-time on-road guidance.

column5: show a map of street parking likelihood
column13: ideally we would select the parking before the trip. It might be harder to evaluate the options after starting the drive.
column17: more precise information, like number of spots available

column5: I think inlacing miles and minutes to the next parking spot would be nice
column9: it's not very obvious what the layer icon means on the top left
column13: The top says distance but then the bar is in minutes. Seems a bit confusing here.
column17: Im not exactly sure how to look at this prototype. I think having street labels would help a lot here.
column18: Prototype 3 - Garage comparison with walk-distance slide
column19: I would prefer p3 because I would personally still go to the parking areas that are labeled as full thinking someone might leave before the app updates. If I still cannot find parking even after that then finding a garage nearby would be my next move.
